sourcesContent:
export const questionObj = {"Qtext": "

In the shown quadrilateral KLMN in the figure, it is given that \(KL = KN \). The bisectors of \(\angle LKM \) and \(\angle MKN \) meet the sides \(LM \) and \(MN \) at the points O and P respectively. Then prove that OP is parallel to LN .
\newline
tikzpicture{}
\newline

", "Steps": [{"id": "s1", "n_params": 0, "step_txt": "
In the triangle LKM , KO is the bisector of $\angle LKM $. So, we can write
\[
	\frac{LO }{OM } = \frac{KL }{KM }
\]"}, {"id": "s2", "n_params": 0, "step_txt": "
$$\text{In the triangle MKN , KP is the bisector of $\angle MKN $. So, we can again write}$$
\[
	\frac{NP }{PM } = \frac{KN }{KM }
\]
\[
	\Rightarrow \frac{NP }{PM } = \frac{KL }{KM }
\]"}, {"id": "s3", "n_params": 0, "step_txt": "
So, from the above two results, we can write
\[
	\frac{LO }{OM } = \frac{NP }{PM }
\]"}, {"id": "s4", "n_params": 0, "step_txt": "
Now in the triangle LMN, OP is a straight line such that 
\[
	\frac{LO }{OM } = \frac{NP }{PM }
\]
That means OP divides two sides of triangle LMN in the same ratio. Which means that OP is parallel to LN . "}, {"id": "s5", "n_params": 0, "step_txt": "Hence proved.
\newline

"}]} 

 export const resp = [{"data": [], "text": "$$\text{Since in the triangle $LKM$, $KO$ is the angle bisector of $\angle LKM$, we can use the angle bisector theorem to write: $\frac{LO }{OM } = \frac{KL }{KM }$}$$"}, {"data": [], "text": "$$\text{In the triangle MKN, since KP is the angle bisector of $\angle MKN$, we can use the angle bisector theorem to write:}$$
\[
\frac{NP }{PM } = \frac{KN }{KM }
\],$$\text{also, since, $KL = KN$, therefore, $\frac{NP }{PM } = \frac{KL }{KM }$}$$"}, {"data": [], "text": " "}, {"data": [], "text": "$$\text{From the converse of Thale's theorem, we can prove that $OP$ is parallel to $LN$.}$$"}, {"data": [], "text": " "}]
